hed: Oreos and the Art of Crossword Puzzle Construction
dek: How a muckbang clip makes it into a crossword puzzle.
intro: This is an investigation into 2020’s most notorious crossword puzzle clue, told at three levels of complexity.

levels.text: Bite-size and snackable, the flavor without the calories.

text.value: “Cookie that some people eat with mustard.” Before 2020 got crazy, this little clue from a USA Today crossword puzzle captivated a nation.
Although the clue is odd, the answer — OREO — is common. It has three of the five most used letters, making it an easy word for puzzle constructors to fill in.

OREO is the seventh most common four-letter answer since 1993, according to a database of over four million clues. This fact also makes its clues stale. "Sandwich cookie" has appeared verbatim over 100 times. So USA Today spiced it up with some mustard, an obscure reference spotted in Shay Mitchell’s pregnancy craving mukbang.

slides.text: Before 2020 got crazy, this little clue from a USA Today crossword puzzle captivated a nation.
Although the clue is odd, the answer — OREO — is common. For starters, OREO is the seventh most used four-letter answer since 1993, according to a database of over four million clues.
Why is it so common? Because OREO has three of the five most used letters, making it an easy word for puzzle constructors to fill in.

text.value: It is not only common, but arguably overused. Let’s say a puzzle is being constructed and there is an answer like _ _ E O. There have been 17 different answers in this scenario, which would mean picking one at random you would get OREO about 6% of the time. However, OREO accounts for 48% of the usage.
Even if you consider the frequency of letters, OREO is only the third most statistically probable, behind words like AREO (Mars prefix) and ATEO (Polynesian god).
Since using OREO is inevitable from time to time, how do you make it interesting? By getting creative with the clue. But with creativity comes criticism.

Not everyone appreciated the obscure reference of the mustard clue, largely in part to the visceral reaction it manifested. A response vaguely reminiscent of the infamous peas-in-guacamole suggestion from the New York Times a few years ago.

slides.text: Like the answer itself, a clue can easily get stale. Here are the most recurring words in clues, and some examples for context.

Unsurprisingly, mustard didn’t appear in a clue until 2020. And what inspired this clue? Despite a citation found in a book from 1972, USA Today editor Erik Agard said credit goes to coworker Jasmine Lim, who spotted it in Shay Mitchell’s pregnancy craving mukbang. Case closed.

slides.text: Before 2020 got crazy, this little clue from a USA Today crossword puzzle captivated a nation.
Although the clue is odd, the answer — OREO — is common. For starters, OREO is the seventh most used four-letter answer since 1993, according to a database of over four million clues.

In the iconic New York Times puzzle, OREO wasn’t used to reference the cookie until 1993, coinciding with the start of the Shortz era. Before that, it was exclusively clued as the Greek prefix for mountain.
For context, this is what Oreos — and life — were like circa 1993, in case you forgot, were too small, or didn’t exist yet.

To understand it’s popularity, we first need to understand letter frequency in puzzles. OREO has three of the five most used letters, making it an easy word for puzzle constructors to piece together with other words.
If we chart a word’s usage vs. its weighted probability of random selection (based on our letter frequencies) we see that OREO is overrepresented.
It was pretty hard to come up with a really unique clue, huh? Well as hard as it is, puzzle constructors have been able to re-invent the clues adding new terms at a fairly regular clip.
